message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Logic of Conditional Doxastic Actions
Paper Abstract: We present a logic of conditional doxastic actions, obtained by incorporating ideas from belief revision theory into the usual dynamic logic of epistemic actions. We do this by reformulating the setting of Action-Priority Update (see Baltag and Smets, 2008) in terms of conditional doxastic models, and using this to derive general reduction laws for conditional beliefs after arbitrary actions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Dynamic logic (modal logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_logic_(modal_logic)"},{"title":"Dynamic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_logic"},{"title":"Dynamic logic (digital electronics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_logic_(digital_electronics)"},{"title":"Dynamic epistemic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_epistemic_logic"},{"title":"Domino logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domino_logic"},{"title":"Hazard (logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hazard_(logic)"},{"title":"Dynamic Business Modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_Business_Modeling"},{"title":"Affect-logics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect-logics"},{"title":"Chaos computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaos_computing"},{"title":"Boolean network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_network"}]

Based on the search results, "dynamic logic" can refer to several distinct concepts depending on the context:

## Modal Logic (Computer Science and Philosophy)

In logic, philosophy, and theoretical computer science, dynamic logic is an extension of modal logic capable of encoding properties of computer programs.(no content)Dynamic logic was developed by Vaughan Pratt in 1974 in notes for a class on program verification and was later published in 1976 as a logical system in its own right.(no content)Beyond its use in formal verification of programs, dynamic logic has been applied to describe complex behaviors arising in linguistics, philosophy, AI, and other fields.

## Digital Electronics

In integrated circuit design, dynamic logic (or sometimes clocked logic) is a design methodology in combinational logic circuits, particularly those implemented in metal–oxide–semiconductor (MOS) technology.(no content)Dynamic logic uses a clock signal in its implementation of combinational logic and exploits temporary storage via voltages on capacitances.

## Dynamic Epistemic Logic

Dynamic epistemic logic (DEL) is a logical framework dealing with knowledge and information change that typically focuses on situations involving multiple agents and studies how their knowledge changes when events occur.

Each of these applications of "dynamic logic" addresses reasoning about change and evolution in different domains—from computer program verification to circuit design to multi-agent knowledge systems.

Web search results for query: "doxastic logic belief"

Links: [{"title":"Doxastic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxastic_logic"},{"title":"Doxastic attitudes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxastic_attitudes"},{"title":"Doxastic voluntarism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxastic_voluntarism"},{"title":"Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_modal_logic"},{"title":"Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_logic"},{"title":"Modal operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_operator"},{"title":"Voluntarism (philosophy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voluntarism_(theology)"},{"title":"Belief - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispositional_belief"},{"title":"Basic belief - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Properly_basic"},{"title":"Ethics of belief - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_belief"}]

Here are the search results for "doxastic logic belief":

## Overview

Doxastic logic is a type of logic concerned with reasoning about beliefs.(no content)The term doxastic derives from the Ancient Greek δόξα (doxa, "opinion, belief"), and typically uses "B" to mean "It is believed that", or when relativized to a particular agent s, "It is believed by s that".

## Doxastic Attitudes

The most commonly discussed doxastic attitude is belief (holding something to be true). Other doxastic attitudes include disbelief (holding something to be false) and suspension of judgment (withholding assent to a proposition without judging it to be true nor false).

## Modal Logic Foundation

Doxastic logic is based on modal logic principles. Doxastic modal operators express belief in statements. This allows doxastic logic to formalize reasoning about beliefs in rigorous mathematical and logical systems.

## Related Concepts

Several related philosophical concepts extend from doxastic logic:

- Doxastic voluntarism is a philosophical view that people elect their own beliefs; this philosophical view is derived from a branch of logic known as doxastic logic.

- Rules or standards that properly govern responsible belief-formation and the pursuit of intellectual excellence are what philosophers call epistemic (or "doxastic") norms.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "epistemic logic"

Links: [{"title":"Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_modal_logic"},{"title":"Dynamic epistemic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_epistemic_logic"},{"title":"Doxastic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxastic_logic"},{"title":"Epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology"},{"title":"Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_logic"},{"title":"KK thesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KK_thesis"},{"title":"Masked-man fallacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masked-man_fallacy"},{"title":"Aristotle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle"},{"title":"Talk:Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Modal_logic"},{"title":"Talk:Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Epistemic_modal_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of epistemic logic:

## Definition

Epistemic modal logic is a subfield of modal logic that is concerned with reasoning about knowledge. More specifically, epistemic logic is a modal logic dealing with the notions of knowledge and belief, and is concerned with understanding the process of reasoning about knowledge and belief: which principles relating the notions of knowledge and belief are intuitively plausible?

## Historical Development

Epistemic logic is a much more recent development with applications in many fields, including philosophy, theoretical computer science, artificial intelligence, economics, and linguistics.(no content)It was not until 1962 that Jaakko Hintikka would write Knowledge and Belief, the first book-length work to suggest using modalities to capture the semantics of knowledge rather than the alethic statements typically discussed in modal logic.

## Key Concepts

The basic modal operator of epistemic logic, usually written K, can be read as "it is known that," "it is epistemically necessary that," or "it is inconsistent with what is known that not."(no content)Most attempts at modeling knowledge have been based on the possible worlds model. In order to do this, we must divide the set of possible worlds between those that are compatible with an agent's knowledge, and those that are not.

## Related Developments

Epistemic logic has been combined recently with some ideas from dynamic logic to create dynamic epistemic logic, which can be used to specify and reason about information change and exchange of information in multi-agent systems.

Here are the search results for belief revision theory:

## Overview

Belief revision (also called belief change) is the process of changing beliefs to take into account a new piece of information.(no content)The logical formalization of belief revision is researched in philosophy, in databases, and in artificial intelligence for the design of rational agents.

## Key Concepts

What makes belief revision non-trivial is that several different ways for performing this operation may be possible. For example, when new information conflicts with existing beliefs, there are multiple rational approaches to resolving the inconsistency.

## The AGM Framework

The AGM postulates (named after their proponents Alchourrón, Gärdenfors, and Makinson) are properties that an operator that performs revision should satisfy in order for that operator to be considered rational. This is one of the foundational frameworks in the field.

## Related Operations

Revision and merging differ in that the first operation is done when the new belief to incorporate is considered more reliable than the old ones; therefore, consistency is maintained by removing some of the old beliefs. There are also other related operations like updating and contraction that handle different types of belief changes.

## Philosophical Context

"What is the rational way to revise one's beliefs when presented with various sorts of evidence?" is one of the notable philosophical debates surrounding beliefs and their revision.

Here are the search results for modal logic:

## Overview

Modal logic is a kind of logic used to represent statements about necessity and possibility.(no content)In philosophy and related fields it is used as a tool for understanding concepts such as knowledge, obligation, and causation.

## Key Features

Modern treatments of modal logic begin by augmenting the propositional calculus with two unary operations, one denoting "necessity" and the other "possibility".(no content)The notation of C. I. Lewis, much employed since, denotes "necessarily p" by a prefixed "box" (□p) whose scope is established by parentheses. Likewise, a prefixed "diamond" (◇p) denotes "possibly p".

## Types of Modal Logic

Hughes and Cresswell (1996), for example, describe 42 normal and 25 non-normal modal logics. Some common systems include:

- The weakest normal modal logic, named "K" in honor of Saul Kripke, is simply the propositional calculus augmented by □, the rule N, and the axiom K.
- S5 is one of five systems of modal logic proposed by Clarence Irving Lewis and Cooper Harold Langford in their 1932 book Symbolic Logic. It is a normal modal logic, and one of the oldest systems of modal logic of any kind.

## Applications

Epistemic modal logic is a subfield of modal logic that is concerned with reasoning about knowledge. While epistemology has a long philosophical tradition dating back to Ancient Greece, epistemic logic is a much more recent development with applications in many fields, including philosophy, theoretical computer science, artificial intelligence, economics, and linguistics.

Additionally, dynamic logic is an extension of modal logic capable of encoding properties of computer programs.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance.

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

I've successfully analyzed the paper "The Logic of Conditional Doxastic Actions" and extracted the key technologies and methodologies:

**Paper Type:** Contribution (the paper proposes a new logic)

**Key Entities Identified (7 triples):**

1. **Belief revision** (uses) - Core theory incorporated into the conditional doxastic logic
2. **Dynamic logic (modal logic)** (uses) - Foundational framework extended with epistemic actions
3. **Doxastic logic** (uses) - Central to reasoning about beliefs in doxastic actions
4. **Epistemic modal logic** (uses) - Foundation for knowledge and belief reasoning
5. **Modal logic** (uses) - Underlying mathematical framework for all logical components
6. **Dynamic epistemic logic** (uses) - Relevant for information change in multi-agent systems
7. **Conditional doxastic logic** (proposes) - The novel logic framework introduced by this paper

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation passed successfully. The triples_output.json file has been updated with all the required information.

Sources:
- [Belief revision](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief_revision)
- [Dynamic logic (modal logic)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_logic_(modal_logic))
- [Doxastic logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxastic_logic)
- [Epistemic modal logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_modal_logic)
- [Modal logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_logic)
- [Dynamic epistemic logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_epistemic_logic)
